newsitem.title: USA: Agriculture discussed at Clinton, EU meeting.
newsitem.headline: Agriculture discussed at Clinton, EU meeting.

text.p: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said agriculture was an important trade issue during Monday's meeting between top European Union officials and President Clinton.
He told USDA Radio that Clinton indicated the two sides had to resolve some pending agricultural disputes such as veterinary equivalency and biotech corn.
Glickman took part in the Washington summit, but EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler was not part of the visiting delegation.

"Both the European Union leadership and the president and I indicated that we thought we could get these resolved but we had to work together to keep them from becoming much more serious trade problems," Glickman said in the radio interview. "So I leave that meeting rather encouraged."
However, Glickman said he was not sure the dispute with the EU over comparable veterinary standards for shipments of animal products could be resolved by a Jan. 1 deadline.

"I think that they are demanding unreasonable things from us right now and we let them know that if the issues couldn't get resolved by Jan. 1 that we ought to give it additional time, because it would be very very bad to start the New Year with this kind of unresolved trade dispute," Glickman said.
